counter_proposal.title: Rights-Proofed, Fiscally Calibrated, and Accession-Anchored Reform Package
counter_proposal.executive_summary: The AI Government would retain all three policy objectives — road safety, seasonal labor formalization, and clinical centre construction — but restructure them as an integrated reform package with mandatory judicial safeguards for expanded police powers, a graduated employer cost phase-in for seasonal worker insurance, and open competitive procurement for the clinical centre within the French bilateral financing framework. Every draft law would include an EU acquis alignment annex and a fundamental rights impact assessment, transforming three standalone decisions into a coherent accession-oriented legislative programme.
counter_proposal.detailed_proposal:
This unified counter-proposal takes the Ministry of EU Integration's accession-anchoring framework as its backbone, integrates the Ministry of Justice's fundamental rights safeguards as a non-negotiable layer, adopts the Ministry of Finance's graduated fiscal approach to employer obligations, and weaves in sector-specific enhancements from the Ministries of Health, Tourism, Education, Environment, Interior, and Economy.

**I. Road Traffic Safety Amendments — Graduated, Rights-Proofed, and Integrated with Public Services**

The young driver restrictions are retained but reformed for proportionality. The blanket midnight-to-5AM driving ban for 18-21 year-olds is replaced with a graduated system that includes documented exceptions for employment, medical emergencies, and areas with no public transport alternatives. This addresses the Ministry of Justice's constitutional concerns (Article 39, freedom of movement; Protocol 4 ECHR) while preserving the core safety objective. The 80kW vehicle power restriction for young drivers is retained as-is, as it aligns with EU graduated licensing norms and raised no proportionality objections.

Vehicle confiscation powers are retained but subject to mandatory judicial review within 48 hours, modeled on existing Criminal Procedure Code asset seizure procedures. Police must obtain supervisor approval and maintain video documentation of every confiscation, as recommended by the Ministry of Interior. Without judicial review confirmation, vehicles are automatically returned. This addresses the most serious rule-of-law concern in the original package.

The deployment of nearly 100 stationary speed radars proceeds but with three additions: (1) a comprehensive data protection chapter aligned with the EU GDPR framework, specifying 30-day maximum retention for non-violation data, access controls, and oversight by the Agency for Personal Data Protection; (2) multilingual advance warning signage (Montenegrin, English, German, Italian) at all radar locations, addressing the Ministry of Tourism's visitor safety concerns; and (3) a public-private concession model for radar procurement and operation, where a private operator bears capital costs in exchange for 25-30% of fine revenue over a 10-year Build-Operate-Transfer contract, eliminating the €5-15 million upfront capital expenditure identified by the Ministry of Finance. The remaining fine revenue is ring-fenced for road safety infrastructure and EMS capacity building.

Road safety education modules are integrated into secondary school curricula — within Civic Education and Health Education subjects — addressing the Ministry of Education's recommendation for preventive rather than purely punitive approaches. The Ministry of Health's call for EMS coordination is adopted: radar deployment corridors are mapped against ambulance response zones, and Level I and Level II trauma centres are formally designated.

A phased geographic rollout begins with high-accident corridors and urban centres (Podgorica, Budva-Kotor-Tivat coastal corridor), expanding nationwide only after enforcement capacity is confirmed — a pragmatic concession to the Ministry of Interior's operational reality.

E-scooter regulation at minimum age 16 with parental liability is retained. Tourist rental operations in designated zones (Kotor Old Town, Porto Montenegro, Budva waterfront) are subject to additional regulation: mandatory insurance, speed limiters at 15 km/h in pedestrian areas, and designated riding corridors near UNESCO sites, as proposed by the Ministry of Tourism.

**II. Permanent Seasonal Workers Law — Fiscally Graduated, Health-Inclusive, and Skills-Linked**

The core concept — a legally recognized 'permanent seasonal worker' with guaranteed re-employment and social insurance continuity — is strongly endorsed across all ministries and retained. However, the implementation is substantially restructured.

Employer cost obligations are phased over three years following the Ministry of Finance's model: state co-financing covers 70% of off-season pension and disability contributions in Year 1, 50% in Year 2, and 30% in Year 3, for employers with fewer than 50 employees. A 'Formalization Tax Credit' provides a 15% corporate tax credit on seasonal wage costs for the first two years for employers who register all workers under the new regime. This directly addresses the risk — flagged by Finance, Economy, and Tourism ministries alike — that immediate full-cost obligations would drive SMEs back into informality.

Year-round RFZO health insurance coverage is explicitly added to the law, closing the critical gap identified by the Ministry of Health. Seasonal workers will maintain access to primary care, chronic disease management, and preventive services during off-season months. Mandatory pre-employment health screenings are required for construction and agriculture workers, aligning with EU Directive 89/391/EEC on workplace safety.

A mandatory 40-hour off-season training requirement is introduced for tourism and hospitality seasonal workers, co-funded by employers (40%), government (40%), and IPA III pre-accession funds (20%). Training covers language skills (English, German), hospitality standards, digital tools, and first aid. Workers accumulate credits toward nationally recognized VET qualifications through a 'skills passport' linked to the National Qualifications Framework, addressing the Ministry of Education's concern about creating structured learning pathways rather than low-skills traps.

A dual-season permanent seasonal worker category is created specifically for northern Montenegro, recognizing the December-March ski season and June-September adventure tourism season. This addresses the Ministry of Tourism's concern that the law was designed around a coastal single-season model.

Environmental compliance is embedded as a condition of employer eligibility: employers in designated coastal zones and national park buffer zones must hold valid spatial planning permits and have no unresolved environmental violations to receive seasonal employment benefits. A percentage of employer social contributions is earmarked for a Coastal Environmental Protection Fund to address waste management and wastewater infrastructure — the Ministry of Environment's core demand. A Strategic Environmental Assessment of the seasonal employment policy's cumulative impact on coastal carrying capacity is commissioned within 12 months.

The seasonal worker registry is built as a digital platform integrated with the Tax Administration, Employment Agency, and — critically — the Ministry of Interior's border management and foreigners' databases, enabling migration tracking and anti-trafficking screening. Mandatory referral triggers to the Organized Crime Unit are established when registration patterns match trafficking indicators. This addresses the Ministry of Interior's law enforcement data integration needs while supporting Schengen readiness.

A fast-track labor dispute resolution mechanism is established for seasonal worker re-employment claims, with 15-day resolution targets, piloted in coastal municipalities. This ensures the right to an effective remedy as required by Article 47 of the EU Charter, addressing the Ministry of Justice's enforceability concerns.

A sunset/review clause at three years triggers a mandatory fiscal, social, and environmental impact assessment before the framework becomes permanent.

**III. University Clinical Centre — Competitive, Clinically Planned, and Transparency-Assured**

The project proceeds under the France-Montenegro bilateral financing framework, but procurement criteria are restructured to balance bilateral obligations with competition, transparency, and healthcare functionality.

The France-headquartered requirement is reframed: the lead contractor must be a French-registered firm (preserving the bilateral agreement), but the consortium must include competitive international subcontracting for specialized components (medical equipment, IT systems, clinical design). A minimum 25% local content requirement mandates Montenegrin subcontracting for construction labor, installation, and maintenance, with mandatory skills transfer and apprenticeship programs. This addresses concerns from the Ministries of Economy, Justice, and EU Integration about restricted competition inflating costs by an estimated 15-30%.

The Agency for Prevention of Corruption (ASK) conducts an ex-ante review of procurement criteria, and a public transparency report justifying the bilateral framework is published. The Ministry of Interior's Organized Crime and Corruption Directorate performs a security and anti-corruption risk assessment before contractor selection. These measures directly respond to the Ministry of Justice's anti-corruption concerns and strengthen Chapter 23 credentials.

A Clinical Services Master Plan is adopted before contractor selection is finalized, defining specialty departments, bed capacity, diagnostic capabilities, digital health infrastructure, and staffing models. At least 15% of facility design must serve teaching, simulation, and research functions, developed jointly with the University of Montenegro's Faculty of Medicine — the Ministry of Education's and Ministry of Health's shared priority.

A Health Workforce Retention Strategy is launched with €15-20 million annual funding for competitive salaries benchmarked to Croatian and Serbian levels, funded specialization programs, and housing subsidies for medical professionals committing to 5+ year service. This addresses the brain drain risk that the Ministry of Health identified as the project's existential threat.

Vague carbon emission reduction language is replaced with mandatory BREEAM 'Excellent' certification (or equivalent), a full Environmental Impact Assessment covering construction and operational phases, and specific medical waste management and infection prevention standards. A 30-year total cost of ownership model — including operational expenditure, staffing, and maintenance — is presented to Cabinet before final contractor selection. Montenegro negotiates a minimum 30% grant element in the French bilateral financing to limit debt impact.

**IV. Cross-Cutting Institutional Reforms**

A mandatory Fundamental Rights Impact Assessment and EU Acquis Alignment Annex accompany every draft law before Cabinet adoption, modeled on the EU Better Regulation Toolbox. This addresses the systemic gap identified by Justice and EU Integration ministries — that legislation is adopted without systematic rights-proofing or accession alignment.

A Cross-Ministerial Youth Policy Coordination Unit with permanent representation from Education, Labour, Transport, and Health is established to ensure policy coherence for the 16-25 demographic most affected by these decisions.

IPA III co-financing applications are submitted for radar deployment (transport connectivity window), seasonal worker social protection extension (social development window), and off-season training programs (human capital development). This leverages EU funds to reduce the national budget burden across all three initiatives.

The Labour Inspectorate receives targeted reinforcement — recruitment, training, and digital tools — funded through IPA III, with specific KPIs for seasonal employment compliance inspections during the May-October peak period.

key_differences: The blanket midnight-to-5AM driving ban is replaced with a graduated restriction system including exceptions for employment, medical emergencies, and areas without public transport — preserving safety objectives while meeting constitutional proportionality standards
Vehicle confiscation requires mandatory judicial review within 48 hours instead of being an unchecked police administrative power
Radar deployment shifts from government-funded capital expenditure to a private concession (Build-Operate-Transfer) model, eliminating €5-15M in upfront costs
Year-round employer insurance obligations are phased over 3 years with state co-financing (70%→50%→30%) instead of immediate full-cost implementation, dramatically improving SME compliance incentives
Year-round RFZO health insurance is explicitly guaranteed for seasonal workers, closing a gap in the original law that mentioned only pension and disability insurance
Off-season training is mandatory rather than optional, converting idle months into skills development linked to the National Qualifications Framework

Clinical Centre procurement opens to competitive international subcontracting with 25% local content requirements, rather than being exclusively restricted to French-headquartered firms for all components
A Clinical Services Master Plan and Health Workforce Retention Strategy must be adopted before contractor selection, not after building completion
Environmental compliance becomes a binding condition for seasonal employer eligibility in sensitive coastal and national park zones
Every draft law must include a Fundamental Rights Impact Assessment and EU Acquis Alignment Annex as standard legislative procedure — a permanent institutional reform
implementation_steps: Weeks 1-4: Draft Fundamental Rights Impact Assessments and EU Acquis Alignment Annexes for all three draft laws; submit to ASK for ex-ante procurement review of Clinical Centre criteria

Weeks 2-6: Amend Road Traffic Safety draft — insert graduated driving ban with exceptions, 48-hour judicial review for confiscation, GDPR-aligned data protection chapter, multilingual signage requirements; conduct proportionality assessment per Venice Commission methodology

Weeks 2-6: Amend Permanent Seasonal Workers draft — add explicit RFZO health insurance guarantee, graduated contribution schedule, Formalization Tax Credit, environmental compliance conditions, dual-season category for northern Montenegro, fast-track dispute resolution mechanism, skills passport provisions, and 3-year sunset clause
Weeks 4-8: Launch competitive procurement process for radar concession (Build-Operate-Transfer), bundling multilingual signage installation with radar deployment

Weeks 4-8: Restructure Clinical Centre procurement criteria — reframe France-headquartered requirement to apply to lead contractor only, add competitive subcontracting for specialized components, insert 25% local content requirement, mandate 15% teaching/research facility allocation
Months 2-3: Commission Clinical Services Master Plan and begin development of Health Workforce Retention Strategy; negotiate minimum 30% grant element with French bilateral partners

Months 2-3: Submit IPA III co-financing applications for radar deployment (transport window), seasonal worker social protection (social window), and off-season training programs (human capital window)
Months 3-4: Build Seasonal Economy Digital Platform integrating Employment Agency, Tax Administration, RFZO, and Ministry of Interior databases; develop anti-trafficking screening protocols
Months 3-6: Recruit and train additional Labour Inspectorate staff; establish joint Tourism-Labour seasonal compliance task force for May-October operations
Months 4-6: Integrate road safety modules into secondary school curricula through Bureau for Education Services; launch e-scooter awareness campaign for 14-18 age group
Month 6: Publish ASK transparency report on Clinical Centre procurement; complete security and anti-corruption risk assessment
Months 6-12: Phased rollout of young driver restrictions — begin with Podgorica and Budva-Kotor-Tivat corridor; deploy first tranche of radar concession
Month 12: Commission Strategic Environmental Assessment of seasonal employment policy impact on coastal carrying capacity
Year 1: Activate seasonal worker law with 70% state co-financing of off-season contributions; launch off-season training pilot in coastal municipalities
Year 2: Reduce state co-financing to 50%; expand radar deployment nationwide; finalize Clinical Centre contractor selection with master plan complete
Year 3: Reduce state co-financing to 30%; conduct mandatory sunset review of seasonal worker law's fiscal, social, and environmental impact
risks_and_tradeoffs: Graduated driving restrictions with exceptions are less restrictive than the original blanket ban, which may marginally reduce the road safety impact for the 18-21 age group — the tradeoff is constitutional durability and reduced likelihood of a successful Constitutional Court challenge that could strike down the entire provision

The 3-year phased employer contribution schedule delays full formalization revenue to the PIO Fund, with the state co-financing costing an estimated €8-15M over three years — but the alternative (immediate full costs) risks 50-60% non-compliance that would generate even less revenue

Opening Clinical Centre subcontracting to international competition may create friction with France under the bilateral agreement — this must be carefully negotiated as enhancing rather than undermining the partnership, and France may resist if the arrangement was predicated on exclusive French participation

The 25% local content requirement for the Clinical Centre assumes sufficient Montenegrin construction capacity exists, which may not be the case for specialized healthcare construction — the requirement may need flexibility provisions

Environmental compliance conditions for seasonal employers add regulatory complexity that could slow formalization in the short term and create enforcement challenges given limited inspectorate capacity

The Health Workforce Retention Strategy's €15-20M annual cost is significant for Montenegro's budget, and competitive salaries may still not match EU-15 levels — brain drain may continue despite investment, though at reduced rates

The PPP/concession model for radars cedes 25-30% of fine revenue to a private operator for 10 years, which represents significant foregone revenue — the tradeoff is zero upfront capital expenditure and transferred maintenance risk

Mandatory Fundamental Rights Impact Assessments for all draft laws will slow the legislative process by an estimated 2-4 weeks per bill — the tradeoff is reduced Constitutional Court challenge risk and stronger EU accession credentials

Cross-database integration of seasonal worker registry with Interior Ministry systems raises legitimate privacy concerns that must be balanced against anti-trafficking and border management benefits through strict data protection safeguards

The cumulative additional budget requirement across all three reformed initiatives (estimated €25-35M annually at peak) is substantial for Montenegro's fiscal envelope, though partially offset by IPA III co-financing, increased formalization revenue, and the PPP radar model
